div.p:
Miss Edgeworth's compliments
to Mrs. Miles and though a
stranger to her she takes the liberty
of begging the favor of her to do
a commission for her & for Mrs. E.

The present riots at Nottingham
make them think that the price
of British lace will rise considerably &
suddenly in England & before
this take place they wish to
buy 2 black pattinette gowns
for which they don't wish to give
more than about 3 guineas apiece
- If not to be had for this price
they would rather do without
them - If Mrs. Miles is so good
as to undertake this commission Mrs.
& Miss E beg s] that she will be good
enough to buy what will make
2 gowns with trains and long sleeves
for two women about five feet high

The patterns to
be a small sprig or leaf something
like the enclosed - that is to say
not a large sprawling pattern
or with any borders which they
think vulgar - they wish to have
the ground of the net very fine &
clear as that makes all the difference
in their appearances - They do not
care whether the gowns are exactly
the same pattern or not so that
the pattern of both be small -
E

Mrs. They beg to have also real
black about lace of not more than inch & half
breadth sufficient for the bosoms
of both gowns and narrow to
match for the sleeves. -
Mrs . and Miss Edgeworth
hope Mrs. Miles will excuse
their giving her this trouble?

postscript.p:
We are not in the least hurry
to have these gowns sent over
to Ireland but merely wish to
have them bought before the
price rises - In spring we will
desire a friend to call for them & bring them over
